sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to Euronews tonight. Our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Remembering David Sassoli. The European Parliament in Strasbourg bids farewell to its late president, who died unexpectedly last week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Pressure is mounting on beleaguered Boris Johnson over the party gate revelations as the British Prime Minister tries to move on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The party gate revelations as the British Prime Minister tries to move on. Ex-President Petro Poroshenko returns to Ukraine to face court on treason charges he dismisses as fabricated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: He could face 15 years in prison if found guilty.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I don't regret it for a second.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Russia's Alexei Navalny calls on his supporters to maintain hope one year after his arrest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And top players Naomi Osaka and Rafael Nadal cruise through the first round at the Australian Open as Novadjokovic returns home to Serbia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Welcome to the programme, I'm Stefan Krobe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: MEPs are coming together in Strasbourg to remember the President of the European Parliament, David Sassoli, who died last week at the age of 65.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Since his sudden death, tributes have poured in for the former Italian journalist who's been praised for his kindness and dedication to his job.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: EU Council President Charles Michel will speak.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Commission President Ursula von der Leyen was due to address the gathering too, but has had to return to Brussels over a COVID scare.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: For more on this, let's go over to Strasbourg, where our correspondent Grégoire Lurie is following events for us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Greg. Good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So, you're at the European Parliament. Describe the atmosphere for us. Good evening, Greg. Good to see you. So, you're at the European Parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Describe the atmosphere for us. There is the memorial today and the election of the new president tomorrow. Is it business as usual?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Hi, Stephan. No, we can't say it is business as usual. As you can imagine, there's an atmosphere of sadness that is dominating here.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The spokesperson of the institution told us earlier that it's going to be a special plenary session, a plenary session that is starting with a ceremony to pay tribute to its president, David Sassoli, who died last week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: to its president, David Sassoli, who died last week. And unfortunately, because of the pandemic, all MEPs won't be able to attend the ceremony and the plenary session. Therefore, it's not going to be a full House that will be here to pay tribute to its president. And the MEPs won't have very much time for remembering their president, because as fast as tomorrow, they will have to elect their new president.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The date was scheduled a long time ago, but they're going to elect their new president tomorrow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Four candidates are running right now, but one name is going ahead from the other.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It is Roberta Mezzola.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: She's the acting president, and she's the candidate from the EPP, the European People's Party, and she's considered as the favorite for this race.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Another name comes to mind, Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: She had to return to Brussels because of Covid. What more can you tell us?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Indeed, Ursula von der Leyen won't be able to attend, but there will be other – there are other high-profile public figures that are attending to the ceremony.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The former Italian prime minister and former MEP Enrico Letta, he's going to give the eulogy to his – for his friend David Sassoli, the European president – the European Council president.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Charles Michel will pay tribute.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: He will be followed by the French President Emmanuel Macron, who's going to talk on behalf of the French presidency of the EU.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But there will be also other leaders attending the ceremony.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Prime Ministers from Italy, Greece, Malta, Luxembourg, Croatia, and also six presidents of Member States' parliaments, will pay tribute to David Sassoli and to show their support to David Sassoli's wife and children who are here in Strasbourg to remember their relatives.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: All right, Grégoire Laurie in Strasbourg for us at the European Parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: David Sassoli's two-and-a-half-year term as European Parliament president was coming to an end before his sudden death.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: MEPs now have to select his replacement, which they'll do on Tuesday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Shona Murray looks at some of the candidates in the running.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The European Parliament is electing its new president remotely, amid the continued threat of Covid-19 infections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Maltese MEP Roberta Mazzola is almost certain to be chosen to replace David Sassoli during Tuesday's vote.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: A frontrunner in the race, the centre-right European People's Party candidate wants to lead a forward-thinking parliament. What we are looking for is a re-energized renewal of a parliament that looks forward with a very modern way of doing politics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Alice Bakunke from the Greens is also in the group of female runners.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: For the Swedish MEP it's key to elect a progressive and skilled leader.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: She says it's not a matter of gender. Finally, the European Parliament's different political groups view competence as the biggest factor that should be what the candidate carries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So I'm very proud to be one of the competent persons and we happen to be several women among the candidates and that's great.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Among other candidates from smaller groups is Spanish MEP Cira Rego representing the far left group. She claims she's running in a symbolic way, but with a wider purpose.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We need to have social muscle, muscle in the public services to face any challenge. We've seen that the COVID-19 crisis has put us in front of the mirror of the vulnerabilities we have when we lose public services.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And we believe that this is a substantial element in addition to employment policies and to dignifying wages.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Polish MEP Kosmas Lodowski from the European Conservatives and Reformists is challenging G3 women.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He told Euronews rule of law is one of the priorities close to his heart.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We are talking about rule of law in Poland for instance or in Hungary, but if we are here in the Parliament doing all according to rule of law, in my opinion, no.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: David Sassoli, the outgoing European Parliament president, died last week. His death came just a few days before completing his two-and-a-half-year mandate and ahead of the election for his successor. Shona Murray, Euronews, Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The pressure on British Prime Minister Boris Johnson over parties held in Downing Street

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: while the rest of the country was in COVID lockdown continues to mount.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Johnson apologised on Wednesday for attending a Bring Your Own Booze event in May 2020, but continues to insist he didn't know it was a party, thinking instead it was an office event.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: But details of more parties have continued to come out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: On Friday, Downing Street apologized to the Queen for an event held on the eve of Prince Philip's funeral.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Opposition Labour Party leader Keir Starmer says Johnson should resign.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Joining me now from London is Tyke Enright.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Tyke.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So, as Johnson is facing more calls to resign, calls even from his own Conservative Party, he rolled out some new policy initiatives. How has the public reacted to that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Yeah, that's right, Stefan. A series of pretty dramatic announcements today, which many believe is a concerted distraction campaign from the scandal surrounding the parties which you've been mentioning. Over the last few days, the newspaper has been full of reports about what has been dubbed Operation Red Meat by Boris Johnson's team. Now, Downing Street has denied that that's what's happening, but many would say that the proof is in the very nature of the announcements themselves. Populist policies designed to appeal to that right wing of the Conservative Party and bring them back on side. Example number one, an announcement to have the Royal Navy deployed to manage the situation with people crossing the English Channel in small boats to seek asylum, something which right-wingers have been calling for for a long time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And on the same day, an announcement that the state broadcaster here, the BBC, will no longer be funded by the TV licence, that form of indirect taxation, after the year 2027.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That has also been a long time issue of contention for right-wingers here. Now plenty of critical voices speaking out against these proposals and calling them out for the distraction campaign that many people believe them to be. I have to say not a lot of the usual people who would expect to be supportive of such measures actually speaking in support of them today, apart from government spokespeople themselves. Meanwhile, there's also a poll of grassroots members of Boris Johnson's Conservative Party, ordinary members, which show that 40% of them want Boris Johnson to resign. Now, perhaps that's because these right-wing policies haven't had enough chance to catch on with the general public, or perhaps that's because these right-wing policies haven't had enough chance to catch on with the general public, or perhaps it's because the public won't be that... won't be distracted by them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So the prime minister obviously facing another tough week, with opposition leader Keir Starmer likely to grill him on Wednesday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: What can we expect?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, certainly, Keir Starmer last week went for the jugular, playing his Trump card by calling for Boris Johnson to resign.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It might be a little trickier for him this week because subsequently we've also had photos distributed of him enjoying a beer with colleagues in a constituency office around the same time as that infamous May 20th party for which Boris Johnson apologised. Now, Keir Starmer says that in his case, and unlike Boris Johnson's excuse, it was actually a work event and he has nothing to apologise for. That said, I wouldn't expect it to hold him back when it comes to his next opportunity to grill Johnson in the Parliament behind me here. It certainly does, though, give Boris Johnson some admonition in response. But, of course, as you mentioned, since that last session, we've heard about four additional parties, not least those two the night before the Duke of Edinburgh's funeral, for which Downing Street has apologised to Buckingham Palace. And, of course, at the rate they've been coming, many people are expecting there could yet be more revelations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And certainly Boris Johnson is facing a very nervous wait between now and whenever it is that that civil servant that he's appointed to investigate all these parties comes out with her report.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It might be at the end of this week, it could be the end of next week, maybe we'll have to wait even longer, we don't know.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And we're waiting to see if she points the finger of blame at Boris Johnson himself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And many even members of his own party have already made up their own minds and they've called on him to resign.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Stefan?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: All right, Taikin, right there in London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Thank you for these updates.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Ukraine's ex-president Petro Poroshenko has appeared in court in Kyiv on charges of high treason.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Authorities are deciding whether to place him in pretrial detention.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Poroshenko addressed supporters who were outside the court.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: He told them he had returned to help protect his country from a possible Russian invasion, despite the risk of arrest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The charges come amid heightened tensions with Russia over its troop buildup along Ukraine's eastern border Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny has called on citizens not to be afraid as he remains imprisoned near Moscow the first anniversary of his arrest Navalny said he does not regret his actions for a second Matthew and the cube has more it was exactly 12 months ago that Russia's opposition leader Alexei Navalny returned to Moscow from Germany after spending months recovering from a poisoning that he blames on the Kremlin and Russian President Vladimir Putin he was detained upon arrival and then sentenced to two and a half years in prison on a fraud charge that he says is politically motivated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Since then his detention has generated international condemnation and increased European Union sanctions on Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But at the same time Russia has also stepped up its crackdown on independent media and opposition activists, forcing many prominent figures into exile.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: One year after his arrest, Navalny said in an Instagram post that he does not regret his actions for a second and called on Russian supporters not to be afraid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: He accompanied this message with a photo of himself in prison uniform alongside his wife Yulia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And this is how Navalny continues to communicate from prison, with official messages posted on social media by his team. And he does continue to generate international attention. Today, Germany's foreign ministry once again called for Navalny's immediate release. An Amnesty International also urged Russia to end brutal reprisals of Navalny's supporters. The closest allies of the Kremlin critic have also been voicing their support on social media, with many suggesting that January 17th could go down in history as the beginning of the end for President Putin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: For now though, Stefan, Navalny continues to remain incarcerated in a Russian prison, and he himself said on Instagram he doesn't know if he will ever be freed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Novak Djokovic, the world's number one male tennis player, has landed back home in Serbia after losing his Australian visa battle over the fact that he is unvaccinated. The fate of Djokovic was played out over two weeks as he was held in detention, then released, only to then have the Australian immigration minister revoke his visa and order his deportation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: He arrived to supporters in Belgrade earlier.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Djokovic could be banned from Australia for three years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The latest from Belgrade airport.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Editor-in-chief at our Euronews Serbia service says it was a warm welcome for the tennis star.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: A huge crowd of reporters and the Novak Djokovic fans were waiting for him at the Belgrade airport.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: He dodged all of them and left for another exit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But it did not stop people from cheering Novak, Novak.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So the passions are still running high about this case, have been for days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Novak has always been the hero of the Serbian nation and now probably more than ever because even those people who in the previous period were critical of his life choices, views and lifestyle are now saying that what happened to him was not right. Overwhelming majority of the Serbs are supportive of him. There's a public outpour of affection and of support.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: A lot of signs in Belgrade, including on the highest building in the city, which was last night illuminated with support messages for Novak.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And everybody is blamingian government for what happened and saying that internal australian politics uh played the key role in the development in in melbourne i think that just it's a shame that what happened to noak that they sentenced him for freedom of choice and speech and i think that only happens in the orwell's books not in the real world but i was wrong and i think i don't know his next steps. I hope that he will find a way to play at the other tournaments while having his freedom of choice to take the vaccine or not. I think it's his own fault, the fault of his team. He has unprofessional people working with him. I'm amazed that the man of the world, such as he is, does not know what a responsibility it is to fill in a form and sign it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Pandemic is a serious thing and they're all on the brink of their nerves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We probably cannot comprehend the level of responsibility they attach to it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So Novak is at the moment in Serbia and we're all waiting to hear what are his further plans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: While Novak Djokovic spent the last few hours on a plane for the rest of the Australian Open players in Melbourne, it was game on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: They started off their campaigns to make it through to the second week of the first Grand Slam of the year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: To discuss that and what's to come, we're joined by sports editor Andy Rubini.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Good evening Andy and thanks for coming on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So there were some strong performances of some serious title contenders. What were the highlights? Well let's start with the local favorite Ashley Barty who completely dominated Sorenco in just 54 minutes at the Rod Laver Arena. The world number one looks in great shape, ready, focused and won 11 games in a row before eventually sealing a win.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Six love, six won.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: She'll next face Bronsetti, who's an Italian qualifier, and she'll be joined by the likes of Victoria Azarenka, two-time champion, Bencic, Svitolina, but also Naomi Osaka, who began her title defence with a comfortable straight-six win over Osorio of Colombia, the 24-year-old.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So Osaka, who said back in 2021 after the US Open that she was thinking of taking another break from the sport to protect her mental health, revealed that she had unfinished business this time around. So I'm sure that'll be reassuring for her fans. In the men's draw, no big surprises either. Alexander Zverev progressed. Also Rafael Nadal making light work of Marcos Giron in straight sets the Spaniard was making his return to Grand Slam tennis after a five-month layoff following a foot injury final score there's 6-1 6-4 6-2 and let me remind you that Nadal is could be on route for a record 21st Grand Slam title let's talk about British hopeful Emma Raducanu. She is back in Grand Slam action tomorrow for the first time since her US Open win and she will face up against 2017 US Open winner Sloane Stephens.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: What's your take on this one?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Well, let's be honest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: I mean, as soon as it was announced, we said this wasn't a good draw for the young Brit Stephens. As you said, 27 US Open champion, loads of experience.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Radu Kanu hasn't had the best prep going into this tournament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: She contracted COVID on her return, lost heavily to Ribakina, 6-0, 6-1.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So I'm not saying she can't win, but these expectations should be realistic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: She's just turned 19.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This is her first full season on the WTA Tour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Her opponents didn't know her back when she was playing at the US Open.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Maybe tactically speaking, they would have sussed her out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So it might be more difficult.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I hope she'll go through because she'll inspire many young tennis players all around the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But I think it'll be tough.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: All right, Andy Rubini, thanks for coming on and bringing us up to date.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The Festival of Fire has returned to the streets of Spain after the pandemic stopped it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Hundreds of people gathered to celebrate the ancient event which sees horses run through flames.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Rebecca Daunt has this story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The crackling of bonfires and the pounding of horses' hooves on the cobblestones.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: These highly anticipated sounds have returned to the Spanish streets of San Barilo de Pinares for the traditional celebration of Luminarias.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We have many beautiful fiestas, but this doesn't exist anywhere else.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The party was cancelled a year ago due to the Covid-19 pandemic. And this year we are here with more enthusiasm than ever. Animal rights groups have complained about this practice which involves riding horses through the flames claiming it's cruel but the inhabitants say they braid the animals manes and tails to ensure they don't burn or suffer. It's one of the best feelings I've had in my life, watching the horses. That is my life, to be with people I love. The smoke, the music. The music is hair-raising when you start hearing it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The festival first began as a reminder of all the animals that died during the plagues that devastated the province two centuries ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: In the beginning we blessed the animals before running through fire.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: That is what we have wanted to preserve and what remains.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And after testing the bravery of the horses and their riders, the embers are used to cook up a feast.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That is something that grows within us and all the people from San Bartolome.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We love it, take care of it, and we live this experience with intensity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: While others take advantage of the heat to endure the bleak midwinter's night.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Rebecca Daunt for Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11

sentences.sentence: Thanks for watching Euronews tonight.
